segments.text: June 15, 1999, my 42nd wedding anniversary.
Perfect.
And sitting in the beautiful living room with Dr. Wayne Hall, looking out on a cloudy morning.
Now, let's see.
Let's check and see if yours is working.
Yeah, it indeed is cloudy today, but I think we'll have some sun before it's over.
I suspect so.
Now let's see.
To a kind of review, you became vice president and dean of the college when?
Well, to start with, my initial appointment under Earl Rutter was simply just dean of the graduate college.
School first, then they changed it to college.
But I soon found out that I was really carrying out the duties of the dean of the college more than I was of the graduate school, informally, no title given.
Because Boyd Page, who had been dean of the college, had left to go to Iowa State University.
I began to wonder how long that might persist or last, because I used to kid Mr. Rutter.
He didn't care for some of my kiddies sometimes.
He was always having me work three jobs for one price.
Well, anyway, the initial appointment was as dean of the graduate college.
I did not become the academic vice president.
I never did officially become the dean of the college.
We never did.
That died with my time at A&M.

But finally, I was able to convince him, along with many others, that he should have vice president for academic affairs, because A&M then was beginning to burgeon and grow and had many different activities than they had in the older days.
So we convinced him.
So he did appoint me dean of the, I mean, vice president for academic affairs.
So your full title was Vice President of Academic Affairs and Dean of the Graduate College.
Yeah, there's a little interesting anecdote about that.
As soon as he was approved there, he said he was going to approve me as Vice President for Academic Affairs.
I said, well, you want me to start looking now for Dean of the Graduate College?
He said, no, I want you to be Dean Hall.
So we just combined my former title with the new one, yeah.
Do you remember when that was?
I was trying to think.
It was around 1960.
I may be off a year or so.
I should have brought in some of my notes.
All right.
The deans of the colleges then, excuse me, of the schools,
were whom?
And please describe them.
Well, the first school to become a college was agriculture.
That happened early in my, when I was dean of the graduate college.
And the dean at that time was Gus Watkins.
who was followed by Pat Patterson later, but that's digressing.
Dean Benson, Fred Benson was dean of engineering.
They were the two largest schools.
Engineering later became a college, but not immediately.
Veterinary medicine was a school for a number of years until about the mid-60s.
Well, it was after the aspiration report was made.
I proposed to Mr. Rutter we needed reorganization and establish some new schools and colleges more in line with what A&M was becoming.
He agreed, and we split off arts and sciences into liberal arts and later education and the College of Science, which immediately was called the College of Science.
Then there was a College of Geosciences formed, because A&M had always been strong in the geosciences, mostly the influence, I guess, of petroleum engineering originally.
And architecture was the last to be split out as a school from engineering.
Describe those four deans, that personality that you dealt with first.
Well, the first dean of the school or college of liberal arts was Frank Hubert, who you know very well.
You know his personality probably better than I do.
But how was he to work with?
Frank was always congenial and easy to work with.
We never had a bit of difference.
I sometimes thought Frank was a little lazy, but that was because I was a gung-ho young man at that time, I guess.
that he let things take its own development, of course, but maybe that was the wisest thing in the long run.
But he ran a good shop, and we gave him the choice later when we split out education, if he wanted to become dean of the college of education he could over liberal arts, and he did accept that.
Did he give any reason why he made that choice?
Oh, Earl Rudder, as well as myself, but I was to learn this.
Earl knew it.
He was strong in the field of education, well respected throughout.
And we wanted to build up education, and we thought he would be the natural.
But we gave him the only, he made up his own mind.
We didn't force him to become dean of, because he enjoyed being dean of liberal arts, too.
What about Benson in personality?
Benson was probably the most capable dean that we've had at A&M, in my experience, in my lifetime.
I mean, I'm sure there were other great ones.
Benson was thoroughly dedicated to engineering, and he was willing to cooperate with others and to get things done.
He was a doer, an achiever, and it sometimes took him longer than he wanted, and he became a little agitated as a result.
But he and I always got along fine, because we were always on the same wavelength.
I got along with the School of Engineering better than I did with some of my own former colleagues in the School of Agriculture or the College of Agriculture, because we saw
things eye to eye, usually, is the reason.
He was one of the deans that would speak up to Mr. Rutter.
The two of us, I think, myself and he were the two that were not afraid a bit of Mr. Rutter.
We would tell Mr. Rutter exactly what we thought, and I think he respected us for it.
I've heard two or three examples of Benson speaking up.
Do you recall any that you can share?
Well, one you already are well aware of was when the Aspirations Report came out, and I guess Mr.
Rudder, in Fred's presence, was complaining or bitching about the faculty didn't know what they wanted to make these recommendations.
Fred said to me, I looked him right in the eye and I said, Mr.
Rudder, if you didn't want the faculty involved, why did you agree to appoint them?
Let them carry out what they recommend.
And how do you think Mr. Rutter evaluated Benson?
I think he thought highly of Fred, yes.
He gave Fred pretty much the people Mr. Rutter trusted and had confidence in.
He gave him a pretty free rein of doing.
Of course, we all checked with him on major decisions.
We never tried to run something by him without
That wouldn't work well, would it?
No.
In fact, you were more apt to get it approved if you took it to him and discussed it in a rational way with him.
Earl could be convinced about the merit of things.
Did he meet regularly with you and the deans?
Well, initially for the first year or so, when I was still just dean of the graduate school, and Dorsey McCrory was his administrative assistant.
The three of us really ran A&M for about three years.
No, there was nothing else.
Well, I say we ran it, of course, with the board's approval of the future protocol.
But I mean on campus.
No, we didn't consult with the other deans.
We just made up our mind what should be done and did it.
And in those days, you could do it.
You couldn't do it in modern times, no.
No, but later I convinced Mr. Rutter that we should have a little more democratic way of administration.
So we formed the Dean's Council.
Mr. Rutter was the chair of it, and I would take it in his absence.
We would meet weekly.
Of course, sometimes it would go two and three weeks when Mr. Rutter was out of town or I was tied up or something.
But I usually would take it over and run it in his absence.
What are the kinds of topics that group would deal with?
They were mostly academic.
We didn't deal with political topics or how to do things or anything like that.
It was just how to get your own job done in your own bailiwick.
In other words, if you were in chemistry, how chemists should be performing.
Did you all discuss new degree programs?
Oh, yeah.
The first five years I was just run ragged in developing new degree plans.
Mr. Rutter and I spent more time over in Austin convincing the coordinator, the director of the coordinating board, who was somebody else before Jack was appointed.
Incidentally, I don't know if you know the story of how Jack came to Texas or not.
No, I'd love to hear that.
Well, I knew Jack when we were both graduate deans.
He was graduate dean for a number of years at Clemson, and we served on a number of committees together.
We had a great high respect for each other.
We liked each other.
He was a very congenial person to get along with, in my opinion.
I think it was Davies, Dr. Davies vacated the coordinating board.
They were asking the university presidents or two university presidents to make recommendations for possible candidates.
And I suggested to Mr. Rutter that I thought Jack Williams would make an excellent coordinator or director of the coordinating board.
And that's the way his name got into the hopper.
I had nothing to do with it after that.
Oh my, I did not know that.
Did not know that.
Because I think it is almost as if somebody upstairs was planning it.
In a way?
The sequence of Rudder and then Williams.
Well, Earl liked Jack, too.
Of course, Jack had been a gung-ho Marine and had great respect for the military.
And he was an outstanding Marine, too, as far as I remember his record.
And Mr. Rutter respected that.
In terms of creating new programs, do you remember any that you thought of as great victories?
And do you remember any that didn't go the way you wanted them to go?
Oh, there were both achievements and disappointments throughout.
I think the reorganization into the schools and colleges, which still largely exist, was one of the real satisfactory achievements.
And developing mainly not only all academic programs, but the new graduate programs.
Because Mr.
Rudder and I agreed early that A&M was never going to mount anything as a university unless we had an outstanding graduate and research program.
That's where we put the emphasis in the early years.
As a result, if you'll check the record, probably during my tenure there and Mr.
Rudder's,
I would say forty percent of the current programs were approved during that time.
We were a frequent visitor over there trying to convince the people in the coordinating board and so forth to approve things.
They almost would laugh that we were members of their staff.
Do you remember any that they snuffed, they turned down?
Initially, they would not approve a college of education.
Mr. Rutter had to use some of his strong influence to finally get it approved, because they thought A&M did not.
There was talk about law and medicine even in those days, but they turned a deaf ear to those in the early days.
They still do, I guess, as far as law is concerned, except the venture down in Houston.
And so the key lobbying in Austin was done by Mr. Rutter and by you and anybody else in those years, in the 60s?
Whenever it was before the board for approval, we would usually, in fact we would always take the dean if they were available to help.
to make the proposal and defend the request.
Yeah, no, we worked not only on the Coordinating Board, but on key legislators, too.
Bill Williams, not Bill Williams, Bill Moore, as you know, carried the ball here pretty much, directly working mostly with Mr. Rutter on it.
Was there even an official A&M lobbyist in those days?
No, not in those early years.
Mr. Rutter did all of that himself.
He wanted to handle the political matters, and he handled them very effectively, in my opinion, too.
How responsive was John Connolly to A&M proposals?
John liked Earl very much, because they were
Politicians of the same kind of cloth, put it that way.
And he used to kid their own and vice versa about the University of Texas versus A&M.
He didn't want A&M to ever get its biggest University of Texas, or to be as outstanding and all this, but thought it was a good-natured banner.
No, he would approve things after a while, but Mr. Rutter always did his homework very effectively.
He would contact the key people that had the clout throughout the state, whether it was in Amarillo or in San Antonio or Houston or Dallas, wherever it was, and he would have his proponents lined up.
came up for action, two or three, if nothing more, telephone calls from these key people would swing the vote when they were reluctant to do it initially.
Were there key allies in the legislature other than Bill Moore?
Well, yeah.
Surprisingly, Swartz, even though he and Bill Moore didn't get along, Earl and I used to go down to cultivate Mr.
to get him to vote on our side.
There were others, I can't recall all the names right now, but some of them were former students and some were not.
And Brownrick Dewey was our representative.
Yeah, he was our longI worked more with Mr. Dewey than Mr. Rutter did.
He worked directly with Bill Moore.
The only time I ever dealt with Bill Moore was when he was unavailable or he was out of town or something had to be done and he would ask me to go.
But I'd have regular meetings with Brown.
Oh yeah, we were, I started to say great buddies, we weren't quite that, but we were good friends.
And he would do almost anything to get anything done for A&M.
He was a great friend of ours too, although he's largely gone unheralded.
He didn't get the press that Bill Moore got.
Let's go through the aspirations and all that, the aspirations report.
As far as you know, where did the idea originate for a kind of an, you started the other day
Telling how it originated?
With the Southern Association self-study.
Yeah.
That's really what prompted it, or at least that's the way I convinced Mr. Rutter that we should do our own personal study.
Not only what was required for the accreditation, but where we really wanted to go and put it down and get key people to endorse it.
If you and I both know, you don't get great ideas approved and endorsed unless you carry the votes for it when it's required.
That's where the aspirations study came about.
Of course, from that was the blueprint for progress, as we called it.
Who selected the individual members of the aspirations committee?
It was a combination of, well, we would get input from any number, but Mr. Rutter and I coordinated the input.
Bill Barzak and I the other day were comparing notes, and neither of us knew how the two of us got on there.
How?
Well, that was through my intersection.
Yeah, I recommended that.
I mean, Mr. Rutter gave me almost free rein of appointing the internal members.
How did you know that we existed then?
This was before Bill and I had worked for you.
Oh, I know.
Yeah, Bill was my first assistant dean of the graduate college that I appointed.
But wasn't this before he was the assistant dean?
Was he already working for you then?
Oh, yeah.
I appointed him almost immediately.
It was the first year I was graduate dean, Mr. Rutter.
How did you identify him?
Well, to be frank, Mr. Rutter wanted me to get somebody who was capable of writing.
because he had a lot of writing assignments and he wanted somebody.
Dorsey would do a lot of it, but Dorsey was not a real, he wasn't an English professor, but he was capable.
So that's one reason, from English.
And we both liked Bill when we interviewed him.
I knew Bill from my professor days.
I got acquainted with almost everybody throughout A&M when I was.
Then as the aspirations report was being done, did anybody keep you informed about what it looked like was forthcoming?
Yeah, I don't know if you recall all of the different committees and subcommittees and so forth.
I know you attended a lot of them, and I tried to attend a lot, and Bill did, and Barczak, and oh, a number of other people.
Mr. Rutter didn't personally attend any of the committee meetings that I ever recall, I mean the faculty or the on-campus committees.
All right, now when we got through
I had the impression that Mr. Rutter was a bit surprised by the breadth of the recommendations.
Yeah, I think honestly now in reflection that Mr. Rutter thought we were trying to cut off too big a piece, a bigger piece than we could chew.
which didn't turn out that way at all.
But I convinced him, and unless you really dream and so forth, you're not going to have high goals to obtain.
A lot of them will never probably reach, but you can't reach them unless you establish that that's where you want to go.
Now, when the final report came in, do you think that his reservations
were based upon the fact that he opposed some of them or that he was fearful simply that he couldn't bring them about.
I think it was a combination of both factors Haskell started with.
No, he didn't agree with everything.
He thought the faculty was trying to seek too big a role for itself.
Mr. Rutter was a strong authoritarian, as you well know, and believed in the power being at the top and descending downward.
Well, he was a former general.
That was his training, and that's what he did well at.
And A&M was a military school when he came here.
Still is, in a way.
And for that era, thank goodness that he had some strength.
Oh, yeah.
There was Mr. Earls.
Mr. Earls, I shouldn't say that.
Mr.
Rudder's tenacity and determination and bulldogging.
A lot of these things would never come about.
Was the board kept well aware of the way the aspirations report looked like it was going?
Not initially, I don't think.
Mr. Rutter was fearful.
I didn't answer fully your last question.

Not only did he think that the faculty had too high an aspiration and wanted too high a lofty goal for itself, but he thought that the board would never approve some of these old-time Aggies that were on the board with influence.
Mr.
Rudder was hesitant that they would ever endorse them.
But he found out that most of them did eventually.
But a lot of the board members and the politicians that had the clout, the political clout in the state, the people that did,
thought the faculty would take its normal course anyway, as most faculty does.
Mr. Rutter thought, as well as a lot of others, the role of the faculty was to teach.
That was it.
It wasn't to politic or to administrate or leave that up to the people that had the power of clout.
Which board members, I think they were still called board of directors then.
Yeah, they were.
Which board members were most positive, and if you know, most negative about the Aspirations Report recommendations?
Well, I don't want to do anybody injustice.
I think Jimmy Aston was one of those that endorsed it quite well, and J. Harold Dunn from Amarillo was a great supporter of it.
Pete Peterson, who had been on the board during that era, had some reservations, but he would do what Mr. Rutter would ask him to do.
Sterling Evans initially had quite a few reservations, although he may say otherwise.
But he eventually came around and was a full backer, yeah.
But initially he had considerable reservations.
Pat Zachary was one of the strong leaders at the time at San Antonio.
And as long as engineering got a place in the sun, Pat would endorse the rest, usually.
But you wanted to make sure the engineering group was taken care of first.
Let's sidetrack on that.
Is one of the consistent features of A&M down through the years the comparative rivalry for first place between engineers and ag leaders?
I'm talking about first place here on the campus.
Is that a kind of consistent part of the story?
I think it is from the founding of A&M when initially that's what they were, agriculture and engineering.
There was considerable rivalry.
Agriculture took off first and probably had that leadership role for a while, and engineering caught up.
But in what I call the modern era,
engineering not only caught up, but probably was rivaling agriculture for a leading role.
Fred Benson was a great person.
Not only was he a strong leader of engineering, but he was a good man to cooperate in anything that was true academic
And I'm assuming, too, this kind of reflected the change of the state of Texas from an agricultural-dominated state to now technologically-dominated.
Yeah.
Well, agriculture is still strong in the state.
In fact, it's probably the leading agriculture school in the country yet.
But it's much more modernized, as you know.
It's more heavily science-based anymore than it was in the older days.
Back to aspirations, do you remember any specific incidents that were kind of symbolic of what happened with the aspirations recommendations?
What happened from them?
Do you remember any specific events that helped to explain the eventual approval of the aspirations report recommendations?
Well, I may be wrong, but this is my interpretation, which I'll state.
I think they were approved and became successful because they were right for A&M.
They were exactly right for A&M.
That's what A&M should have.
In fact, I used to yelp to Mr. Rutter in the early days.
unless we establish where we want to go and really build this, you're never going to have a place in the sun.
You'll probably lose out for all time.
Well, and I agree, particularly looking back now, if we hadn't done it about then,
We'd be so far behind.
Oh, right.
If we hadn't become coeducation and a number of other things, A&M would be a fourth-rate institution now.
One of the recommendations that didn't get approved was the name change to Texas State University.
Who came up with the abbreviation A&M as it is now?
Well, as simple as just a name change might seem to some people,
It actually took more time with Mr. Rutter and Dorsey McCrory and I on these evening long battles than any other subject initially.
And then it had the same fate when it went to the dean's council, to the academic council, all along the way.
People just couldn't agree on what the name should be.
And finally,
As I recall, I suggested that we call it university.
Everybody agreed it had to be university.
But what university?
And I said, well, the heritage of the past is A&M.
That stands for agriculture mechanical.
Well, let's forget about it.
Let's just put capital A without period, capital M without period.
and call it, because we are in the state of Texas, Texas A&M University.
Eventually, after a lot of harassment and disappointment, it was approved.
Mr.
Rudder didn't like it originally.
He used to say, well, what does A&M without periods really stand for?
Now, did he have a favorite, or do you remember?
I'm trying to recall.
He did at one time, although he was mostly more of a devil's advocate about names that were suggested and then suggesting them himself, as I recall.
Dorsey McCroy just used to reel them off by the dozen in our personal discussions.
In these private discussions of you and Mr. Rutter and or you and Dorsey and Mr. Rutter,
Clearly, it was okay for people to say exactly what they thought.
In other words, you could, in those discussions, you... Oh, I mean in our personal discussion?
Yes.
Oh, yeah.
We often had quite heated debates, but nothing in anger.
You're right.
I mean, it was just forceful to...
enthusiastic debate.
Mr. Rutter wasn't afraid to say, you're crazy as hell.
I would never say that to him.
I used to try to convince him in a rational way what something that he wanted done wasn't feasible or shouldn't be done.
Do you remember any examples of where he literally changed his mind?
He started down this way and eventually ended up over here?
Yeah, there was a number of things that came about that he initially was opposed to.
He didn't want the name change to start with.
He definitely didn't want coeducation, and he didn't want the voluntary corps.
But he came to them.
Admission requirements, did that, to gradually make those more restrictive, did that bother anybody?
Initially, Mr. Rutter used to question me when I was saying, well, you've got to tighten the screws on a mission.
I tried to convince him that high standards didn't turn students away, that sometimes low standards did, too low standards.
And it took a while to convince him.
In fact, he was concerned because enrollment was falling when he came here.
it had to be beefed up or A&M wasn't gonna survive.
That was as simple as that.
And so he was concerned that we might turn students away.

But I finally convinced him, and after showing him what was happening, that higher standards was the thing that would attract the outstanding students, along with the President's scholarships that we established.
There's various versions how that got established.
I've read them myself.
But I can tell you frankly how it got established.
Earl Rudder asked me to draw up the recommendations to form them.
